titles: Erasmus+
details: Question for written answer E-008545/2016to the CommissionRule 130Miriam Dalli (S&D)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content:
The Commission recently announced an extra EUR 300 million budget for Erasmus+, the EU’s programme on education, training, youth and sport for the 2014-2020 period.
1. How does the Commission intend to promote projects that can support social inclusion for all?
2. How will the establishment of the European Solidarity Corps create opportunities, raise the social contribution made by young people and strengthen solidarity in the face of varied human and social crises?

titles: Practical guide to the legislation that applies to workers
details: Question for written answer E-011058/2013to the CommissionRule 117Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
The Commission’s practical guide to the legislation that applies to workers in the EU, the European Economic Area and Switzerland was well received by the Member States and attracted great interest, since it was translated into all the EU’s official languages. 
However, only the English version of the guide has been updated following the amendment of Regulations (EC) Nos 883/2004 and 987/2009 on 28 June 2012. The amendments particularly affect Part II of the guide.
The Commission’s website states that the other language versions will be updated in due course. Almost a year later, the other language versions are not yet available. 
When can the translation of the practical guide into the EU’s other official languages be expected?

titles: Breaches of the Birds Directive in Malta
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Bart Staes (Verts/ALE), Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE), Marie Isler Béguin (Verts/ALE), Paulo Casaca (PSE), Dorette Corbey (PSE), Robert Evans (PSE), Wolfgang Kreissl-Dörfler (PSE), Karin Scheele (PSE), Caroline Jackson (PPE-DE), Péter Olajos (PPE-DE), Neil Parish (PPE-DE) and Jonas Sjöstedt (GUE/NGL)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats
content:
Is the Commission aware of the several press articles that are being published almost every day in Maltese newspapers on cases of infringements of the Birds Directive and the derogation on trapping that Malta has been granted during its accession negotiations with the European Union?

Does it recognises that a huge problem of illegal hunting and trapping of (protected) birds still exists in Malta and if so, what kind of measures will it take to wind up such practices?

titles: Council Regulation 3254/91 - Use of leghold traps
details: Question for written answer E-001948/2016to the CommissionRule 130Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content:
Under Council Regulation 3254/91, the use of leghold traps has been illegal since 1991. In a number of Member States such a ban has been in place even longer. Despite the ban on the use of leghold traps at both the national and the European levels, the sale of imported products based on the capture of live animals with leghold traps still takes place.
1. Does the Commission consider there may be a legal basis within current European legislation to stop the import of products which, under European law, are produced with an illegal and/or inadequate attitude to the safeguarding of animal welfare, such as fur products made from animals captured with the use of leghold traps?
2. If this is not the case, does the Commission propose to put forward new legislation in this area which would make such a ban possible?
3. Does the Commissioner think it is compatible with the spirit of the existing animal welfare strategy to continue allowing the importation of products based on production methods which are indefensible as regards animal welfare?

titles: Albacore tuna fishing in the North Atlantic
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Josu Ortuondo Larrea (Verts/ALE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
The Commission has presented its proposal for a regulation establishing technical measures to correct the situation of certain populations of highly migratory species.
Amongst other things the regulation incorporates the 1998 and 1999 ICCAT (International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas) recommendations on restricting fishing capacity or effort in respect of albacore tuna by limiting the number of vessels which will in future be allowed to fish to the average recorded during the 1993-1995 period.
Given that the current fishing season's activity in this fishery has already commenced, it can be assumed that the Commission has received the relevant data from each of the Member States involved and has checked and validated it with a view to establishing the average number of vessels authorised in the 1993-1995 period, on the basis of which it was to fix the maximum number of vessels authorised to fish in 2000.
Can the Commission supply the total annual figures for each EU Member State with regard to the number of vessels authorised to fish and actually doing so continually and to the full extent in the albacore fishing seasons in the North Atlantic in each year of the reference period, i.e. in 1993, 1994 and 1995?
What is the average established for each Member State with regard to vessels authorised to fish for albacore and actually doing so continually during the period 1993 to 1995?
Can the Commission provide a breakdown by Member State of the total number of vessels authorised to fish for albacore in 2000?

titles: Organisational deficiencies in the Structural Funds
details: Question for written answer E-010696/2010to the CommissionRule 117Andreas Mölzer (NI)
party: Non-attached Members
content:
An investigation into the effectieveness and efficiency of the EU structural funds by a Financial Times team in collaboration with the Bureau of Investigative Journalism of City University London came to the conclusion that the structural funds system is too bureaucratic and that the money is taken up mainly by large corporations and well-off beneficiaries.
An article of 30 November 2010 in the daily Die Presse under the headline ‘EU study: A lot in the wrong hands, not much in the right’ reports that ‘instead of supporting small and medium-sized undertakings, money goes to corporations such as IBM, Fiat, Nokkia, Siemens, H&M or Coca Cola. Other companies received funds when they were moving their factories to countries with cheaper workforces. EUR 1.6 million was paid out to British American Tobacco for a cigarette factory, although at the same time millions are being spent on anti-smoking campaigns. The structural funds programme has become an opaque bureaucracy, the critics say. Organised crime repeatedly gets its hands on EU aid without difficulty. And the underdeveloped regions that the programme is supposed to help get little because in times of economic crisis their national governments cannot afford to provide the co‑financing required.’
1. What is the Commission’s reaction to the reproach that the structural funds are overbureaucratic and opaque?
2. What measures are planned to make it harder for organised crime to get hold of EU funding?
3. Are there plans to make it easier for small and medium-sized firms to gain access to funding?
4. If so, what measures will be put in place?
5. If not, why not?
6. EU rules on aid for relocation of production have been tightened up. Have studies been carried out to see whether these tighter rules have borne fruit, and have penalties been imposed in this context?

titles: Money for funding networks
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Mikel Irujo Amezaga (Verts/ALE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
There is still a major disparity between different EU Member States (and between regions within the same) with regard to the availability and quality of the networks linking cultural institutions, schools, universities and different scientific and cultural centres. For remoter, non-interconnected and thinly-populated regions, this involves tremendous costs.

For example, Portugal, which, located in a remote corner of the EU, has difficulties in building a proper network of this kind, has requested to use the Structural Funds to this end. We could also cite thinly-populated Slovenia, where the per capita cost to the taxpayer is greater than in most Member States.

The DG REGIO, by means of its Structural Funds, makes possible the part-funding of these e-infrastructures, but the truth of the matter is that in the countryside there are very few educational institutions.

Does the Commission not think that it would be useful to set up some funds directly designed to fund projects of this kind in order to promote these networks, and thus make progress to achieving genuine ‘freedom of knowledge’ within the EU?

titles: Monte Paschi scandal: failure to calculate the cost of derivatives deals
details: Question for written answer E-000950/2013to the CommissionRule 117Roberta Angelilli (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, which is quoted on the Stock Exchange and active, as well as in Italy, on European and international markets, is at the centre of a scandal involving dubious trading on the derivatives market, which, in addition to causing mass selling of the bank’s shares, is giving rise to immense anxiety among current-account holders and its employees, of whom there are about 30 000.
On 17 December 2012 the Commission, acting under EU State aid rules, temporarily approved a EUR 3.9 billion recapitalisation of Monte Paschi in order to preserve the stability of the Italian financial system and enable the bank to comply with the recommendations of the European Banking Authority. The approval is subject to a requirement to submit a restructuring plan by May 2013.
In his State of the Union Address on 12 September 2012 the Commission President, José Manuel Barroso, had this to say about banks: ‘when things went wrong, it was the taxpayers who had to pick up the bill’.
Today the Monte Paschi scandal is proving the truth of that assertion.
In the light of the foregoing:
1.
Can the Commission explain why the recapitalisation was temporarily approved when there had been no proper analysis of the bank’s financial stability or its use of derivative financing?
2.
Does it believe that checks should be built into the agreement on Europe-wide banking supervision in order to avert further cases of this kind, especially where the derivatives market is concerned?
3.
What information was given to Monte Paschi current-account holders to help protect their savings?

titles: Iași emergency hospital
details: Question for written answer E-004845/2020/rev.1to the CommissionRule 138Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content: The new Union Civil Protection Mechanism, involving the establishment of additional European medical, technical and logistical emergency treatment facilities for patients with critical injuries (burns, multiple trauma) in the Member States, is a necessary measure that was approved by Parliament on 16 September 2020 (report A9-0148/2020).  Can the Commission say whether the Iași emergency hospital will benefit from these arrangements?

titles: Burma
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Pietro-Paolo Mennea (NI), Marco Cappato (NI), Benedetto Della Vedova (NI), Lucio Manisco (GUE/NGL), Mario Borghezio (NI), Roberto Bigliardo (UEN), Luisa Morgantini (GUE/NGL), Carlo Fatuzzo (PPE-DE), Giovanni Fava (PSE), Marco Pannella (NI), Generoso Andria (PPE-DE), Vitaliano Gemelli (PPE-DE), Gianfranco Dell'Alba (NI), Sebastiano Musumeci (UEN), Pasqualina Napoletano (PSE), Amalia Sartori (PPE-DE), Giovanni Pittella (PSE), Mariotto Segni (UEN), Luigi Cocilovo (PPE-DE), Walter Veltroni (PSE), Giorgio Ruffolo (PSE), Raffaele Costa (PPE-DE), Luigi Cesaro (PPE-DE), Paolo Pastorelli (PPE-DE), Adriana Poli Bortone (UEN), Fiorella Ghilardotti (PSE), Giovanni Procacci (ELDR), Claudio Martelli (ELDR), Mauro Nobilia (UEN), Antonio Mussa (UEN), Renato Brunetta (PPE-DE) and Olivier Dupuis (NI) to the Commission
party: Group of the Party of European Socialists
content:
According to press reports, the ruling military junta in Burma (now called Myanmar), which is headed by General Khin Nyunt, has sentenced to death Zaw Thet Htway, aged 37, the editor of the sports magazine First Eleven.

Zaw Thet Htway is alleged to have conspired, along with colleagues, to assassinate the leaders who are oppressing that country through their dictatorial regime. No official warrant was issued for the journalists' arrest and their trial was conducted without the assistance of any lawyers not subject to pressure or external influence and without international observers, who could have guaranteed if not a fair trial then at least one that reflected the fundamental principles of justice. Zaw Thet Htway and the eight other defendants were sentenced to death and confined to a special prison.

All these people have done is to voice a critical opinion of the regime led by General Khin Nyunt by denouncing the misdeeds, abuses and harassment which the people of Burma have been suffering for too long now. The members of this dictatorship have, in fact, over the years, spirited away international donations to the value of several million dollars which were actually intended for the world of sport, to construct and renovate facilities, purchase sports equipment and clothing, and promote football throughout the country.

The military government, on the other hand, has gone so far as to appropriate funds earmarked for sport, without the merest fraction of the money received being allocated to the ends for which it was intended, in order to maintain the current system, which is corrupt, repressive and flies in the face of the most fundamental democratic principles.

In practice, a criticism and negative opinion of this corrupt system has been transformed into an 'illegal' conspiracy against the state, and therefore one punishable by death.

Will the Commission use the powers conferred upon it to intervene to ensure the suspension and revocation of this death sentence, thereby saving the lives of the nine accused, and to safeguard the most fundamental principles of civilisation and democracy that should be applied to all citizens of a democratic nation, in line with the dictates of the European Union?

titles: Ending street homelessness
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Mary McDonald (GUE/NGL), Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), Gérard Onesta (Verts/ALE), Stephen Hughes (PSE), Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (GUE/NGL), Bairbre de Brún (GUE/NGL), Elspeth Attwooll (ALDE), Eva-Britt Svensson (GUE/NGL), Anne Van Lancker (PSE), Richard Corbett (PSE), Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE), María Valenciano Martínez-Orozco (PSE), Javier Moreno Sánchez (PSE), Proinsias De Rossa (PSE), Erik Meijer (GUE/NGL), Dimitrios Papadimoulis (GUE/NGL), Adamos Adamou (GUE/NGL), Kyriacos Triantaphyllides (GUE/NGL), Lívia Járóka (PPE-DE), Neena Gill (PSE), Maria Matsouka (PSE), Martine Roure (PSE), Jan Andersson (PSE), Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), Evangelia Tzampazi (PSE), Jacek Protasiewicz (PPE-DE), Edit Bauer (PPE-DE) and Umberto Guidoni (GUE/NGL) to the Council
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
Headlines on rough sleepers freezing to death can be read all over Europe during these early winter months of 2006, urging policy‑makers to respond with ‘winter emergency plans’ and prompt and outreach help to victims of the cold. Homelessness has been one of the main priority areas under the EU social inclusion strategy 2001‑05 (a strategy now streamlined with health and pensions to form one streamlined strategy on social protection and inclusion), and this was confirmed at the March 2005 EPSCO Council and at the October 2005 UK Presidency Round Table on social inclusion.

Can the Council outline what actions have been taken to follow through on the commitment by European Social Affairs Ministers to treat homelessness as a priority and set a European objective to end street homelessness by 2010?

titles: Solutions to problems raised by the construction of the Zaragosa Logistics Platform ('Plaza') in terms of dealing with the growing volume of freight traffic between Spain and France
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Erik Meijer (GUE/NGL), Eva Lichtenberger (Verts/ALE) and Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
1. Is the Commission aware that the possible further development of the ‘Plaza’ logistics platform near Zaragoza will, if the Zaragoza-Toulouse rail line is not built in time, above all lead to a further increase in HGV traffic on the two major trans‑border road links between Spain and France that are open all year round, at Irún/Hendaye in the west and Jonquera/Le Perthus in the east, and that these links, which are already suffering from traffic jams, will become completely blocked?

2. How great is the risk that, if the rail link desired by the Spanish side does not go ahead, a motorway running through the Pyrenees in the Aspe valley, partly paid for from funding for trans-European networks, would attract the large volume of freight transport expected to be generated between Zaragoza and Toulouse, leading to this transport being carried out in a way which would have an unnecessarily negative impact on the environment? Would a possible alternative be to bring the French railway line running between the border town of Canfranc in the Pyrenees and Pau (Somport), which has been closed for a long time, back into use, and could this save costs?

3. How does the Commission view the Spanish plans within the context of short sea shipping measures and improvements to the existing rail infrastructure on the Mediterranean and Atlantic sides, including from the point of view of cost‑benefit aspects?

4. Does Spanish opposition to higher toll charges for road freight transport (Eurovignette) play a part in the Commission's assessment of the contribution to be made by the EU to possible solutions to the anticipated traffic congestion?

5. Does the Commission agree that, as a result of a lack of coordination between decisions taken by the Spanish and French sides, there is the risk of investments going wrong, unnecessarily large new traffic flows being created and a serious threat being posed to the environment?

6. Does the Commission consider that it has a role to play in providing advice to the Member States, regions and local authorities concerned regarding positive solutions, facilitating cross-border coordination and advising against unsound or unrealistic plans, or is it adopting a wait-and-see attitude to these projects failing and new problems being caused?

titles: The common fisheries policy and regional development
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Daniel Varela Suanzes-Carpegna (PPE-DE) to the Commission
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats
content:
For the purpose of assessing the common fisheries policy's impact on, and contribution to, regional development, the Commission has launched the QLRT‑2000‑02277 research project, which is concerned with devising a calculable general-equilibrium model and applying it to the analysis of the contribution which fishing makes to regional development.

In its reply of 14 June 2005 to my earlier Parliamentary Question E‑1766/05, the Commission informed me that the project had not been concluded as planned in January 2005; it would be concluded in June 2005 instead and I would be sent a copy. Since it is now 7 November and I have yet to receive any news from the Commission, I call once again upon the Commission to notify me of the outcome of the project and to send me a copy of the final report.

Can the Commission now provide me with that information and explain the reasons which account for the fact that the project is now considerably behind schedule?

titles: Expressions of interest in the Sixth Framework Programme of Research for embryo research and stem cell research
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Elly Plooij-van Gorsel (ELDR) to the Commission
party: Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party
content:
On 20 March 2002 the Commission published an invitation to submit expressions of interest in the Sixth Framework Programme of Research (FP6). Until 7 June 2002, scientific institutes and businesses could submit plans to the Commission for assessment as to their suitability for support from the Framework Programme. On 4 October 2002 the Commission published the results.

From the published results it emerges that in 1997 expressions of interest were submitted for the thematic priority "Life sciences, genomics and biotechnology". This priority includes financial support for stem cell research.

The regulation of human embryonic stem cell research is subject to subsidiarity in Europe, and different practices exist in the Member States in this regard. In some Member States, for example, it is permitted to produce human embryos for research purposes, whereas in other Member States this is explicitly prohibited.

Under the compromise reached between the Council and the European Parliament in September 2002 concerning the five specific programmes within the FP, it was agreed that until the end of 2003 the Commission should not finance any research programmes which included embryonic stem cell research.

1. How many expressions of interest have been submitted to the Commission under the thematic priority "Life sciences, genomics and biotechnology" which involve embryonic stem cell research?

2. In which Member States are the scientific institutes and/or businesses based which submitted these expressions of interest?

titles: Slaughter of wolves in Sweden
details: WRITTEN QUESTION E-0355/10by Cristiana Muscardini (PPE)to the Commission
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
In recent years the leading European industrialised nations have made progress in terms of protecting, respecting, and preserving animal rights by adopting Community legislation to regulate the hunting and conservation of protected species such as the wolf.
Sweden has passed an Act of Parliament allowing wolves to be legally hunted until 15 February.
Conferring legitimacy in this way could encourage poaching, with the risk that entire populations of endangered species might be drastically reduced.
1. Is the Commission aware of the above law?
2. What steps has it taken in response to the Swedish action, which is objectively contrary to Community regulations?

titles: Secretary General of the European Schools
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Umberto Guidoni (GUE/NGL), Herbert Bösch (PSE), Jan Mulder (ALDE) and Bart Staes (Verts/ALE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
Can the Commission confirm that it has requested an audit of the office of the Secretary General of the European Schools?

If so, is it correct that the Secretary General of the European Schools did not give permission for such an audit? 

If this was the case, did the Commission receive any explanation about the refusal of the Secretary–General and if so, what justification did the Secretary General provide to the Commission?

What measures does the Commission envisage in order to make sure that such an audit will be allowed?

titles: The position and measures taken by the Commission concerning the British fur ban
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Piia-Noora Kauppi (PPE-DE), Ari Vatanen (PPE-DE),Ilkka Suominen (PPE-DE), Karl von Wogau (PPE-DE), Roger Helmer (PPE-DE),Malcolm Harbour (PPE-DE), Struan Stevenson (PPE-DE), Den Dover (PPE-DE),Astrid Lulling (PPE-DE), John McCartin (PPE-DE), Dana Scallon (PPE-DE),Marjo Matikainen-Kallström (PPE-DE), Christian Rovsing (PPE-DE),James Provan (PPE-DE), James Elles (PPE-DE), Charlotte Cederschiöld (PPE-DE),Karla Peijs (PPE-DE), Elly Plooij-van Gorsel (ELDR), Bertel Haarder (ELDR),Charles Tannock (PPE-DE), Paul Rübig (PPE-DE), John Purvis (PPE-DE),Markus Ferber (PPE-DE), Christian von Boetticher (PPE-DE),Thierry Cornillet (PPE-DE), Robert Goodwill (PPE-DE), Astrid Thors (ELDR),Giles Chichester (PPE-DE), Konrad Schwaiger (PPE-DE), Bashir Khanbhai (PPE-DE),Robert Sturdy (PPE-DE), Earl of Stockton (PPE-DE), Mikko Pesälä (ELDR),Samuli Pohjamo (ELDR), Jonathan Evans (PPE-DE), Jacqueline Foster (PPE-DE),Carmen Fraga Estévez (PPE-DE), Jan Mulder (ELDR),Encarnación Redondo Jiménez (PPE-DE), Francesco Fiori (PPE-DE),Arlindo Cunha (PPE-DE), Hedwig Keppelhoff-Wiechert (PPE-DE),Elisabeth Jeggle (PPE-DE), Joseph Daul (PPE-DE) andReino Paasilinna (PSE) to the Commission
party: Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party
content:
Member States had until 13 March to react to the draft UK ban on fur-farming. Five Member States (Italy, France, Finland, Spain and Denmark) voiced very serious concerns about the measure, and France submitted a detailed opinion opposing its adoption. As the Commission is aware, this proposal has no scientific basis (nor does the UK claim that it has), and the justification put forward for it by the UK authorities is public morality.
As the Commission is aware, fur-farming is a well regulated sector of agriculture governed by national and EU laws as well as by a Council of Europe Recommendation on fur animals which was adopted in June 1999 with the support of all EU Member States and the Commission. The EU is the largest producer of farmed fur, and the sector provides thousands of jobs, both directly and indirectly.
In view of this situation, does not the Commission consider it illogical and incorrect for a Member State to ignore EU laws governing a legitimate agricultural activity and ban it without full and proper justification? Is not the Commission concerned about the precedent that would be set if a ban based on unsubstantiated public morality arguments were accepted, and is it not worried that the same basis might be used to ban the keeping of other farmed animals or to introduce measures on the transport of animals that conflict with EU directives in this field?
Finally, in the light of the above, does not the Commission consider that it should take a position against the draft UK ban as a matter of urgency and join France in issuing a detailed opinion?

details: no questions
party: Forza Europa Group
content: NA

titles: Human rights in Vietnam
details: Question for written answer E-004449/12by Mara Bizzotto (EFD)to the Commission
party: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
content:
On 12 April 2012, in Vietnam, a Christian pastor was the victim of a vicious assault by armed attackers, who not only beat the cleric but also destroyed the orphanage he had opened, and threatened workers and children. From the evidence available, it appears that local police and authorities colluded in this attack, with the police being present at the site specifically in order to keep Christians away and ensure that the attack was successfully concluded. Calls from the Bishop of Hanoi for an investigation to be opened into the matter have been ignored.
Is the Commission aware of this incident? 
Can it provide an update on the situation of Vietnam’s Christian community?
Can it say whether the issue of human rights was addressed during the 11th ASEAN-EU meeting held in Phnom Penh, in particular during the EU‑Vietnam side meetings at which a document setting out the scope of future trade negotiations was drafted?

titles: Customs classification for mobility scooters
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Fiona Hall (ALDE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
content: An EU Customs Code Committee decision reclassified ‘carriages for disabled persons’ as ‘motor vehicles for the transport of persons’. Why was this change in classification made? The change has resulted in an increase in import duty, and these costs are being passed on to disabled consumers, with the price of mobility scooters increasing significantly. Will the Commission ask, via the EU Customs Committee, for the change in classification to be reconsidered?

titles: Promoting the use of electric cars in the EU
details: Question for written answer E-008771/2015to the CommissionRule 130Gabriel Mato (PPE), Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
Travelling in electric or hybrid cars reduces CO2 emissions and pollution in cities. Nevertheless, there are still some barriers to consumers purchasing these vehicles, some of them related to the scarcity of service stations where they can be recharged. 
What steps is the Commission taking to encourage the use of electric cars in the EU? 
What steps is the Commission taking to enable the installation of more recharging stations for these vehicles?

titles: Establishing ways of monitoring the rights of paperless child migrants
details: Question for written answer E-000507/2015to the CommissionRule 130Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
Based on the Stockholm Programme — An open and secure Europe serving and protecting citizens (Official Journal C 115 of 4 May 2010) — DGs Home and Justice have forged ahead with legislation recognising and protecting children’s rights. The specific fields involved are human trafficking, sexual exploitation and victims' rights. 
Nevertheless it is important that the EU satisfies itself that Member States are actually fulfilling their legal and policy commitments deriving from the work of the DGs and that they all, without exception, uphold the rights and protection of all children within their jurisdictions.
With regard to the rights of undocumented child migrants, and within the frameworks of protection set up in points 2(3)(2) and 2(3)(3) of the Stockholm Programme, has the Commission arranged to channel efforts and resources into establishing ways of monitoring respect for such rights at Member State level?
Does it also plan to review the proper implementation of the relevant public policies? Is it considering punitive action when infringements occur?

titles: Transfer of Macao to Chinese administration - death penalty
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by José Barros Moura(PSE) to the Council
party: Group of the Party of European Socialists
content:
The recently renewed EU-Macao agreement contains a commitment for the parties to respect human rights.
In recent statements, the Member of Parliament and member of the Preparatory Commission Vitor Ng has accepted the reintroduction of the death penalty in that territory following its reintegration into the sovereignty of the People's Republic of China.
Nevertheless, the territory's penal code - which recently came into force after being adopted with the assent of the Chinese side in the Joint Liaison Group and the remaining in force of which (together with all other legislation applicable at the time of the transfer of sovereignty) was the subject of a commitment given by the authorities of the People's Republic of China in the Sino-Portuguese joint declaration and in the Basic Law of the Special Administrative Region of Macao - not only makes no provision for the death penalty but expressly provides for its prohibition and abolition.
How does the Council assess the implications of the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Macao from the point of view of the CFSP and EU trade policy, which must respect human rights?

titles: Derogations under Article 9 of the Drinking Water Directive 1998-2018
details: Question for written answer E-002667/2018to the CommissionRule 130Rory Palmer (S&D)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content: How many derogations were granted to Member States between 1998 and 2018 under Article 9 of the current Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC) framework, and what were the reasons for each of these derogations being granted?

titles: Design and construction of Sofia's high-speed northern bypass using European funds
details: Question for written answer E-010212/2013to the CommissionRule 117Alfredo Pallone (PPE), Aldo Patriciello (PPE), Gino Trematerra (PPE), Fabrizio Bertot (PPE), Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
On 29 April 2013, after participating in the open tender procedure and offering the most financially advantageous bid for designing and constructing Sofia’s high-speed northern bypass (from 0+000 km to 16+540 km), the Salini‐Impregilo joint venture had received notification of being awarded the contract (ARI Decision No 52/29.4.2013) by the Bulgarian Agency for Roads and Infrastructure (ARI) for the highest score achieved, based on the technical proposal and implementation times envisaged.
As a result of an appeal lodged by two of the other participants, Porr Bau GmbH (Austria) and the HPVS‐SST consortium (Bulgaria), the Bulgarian Commission for the Protection of Competition (CPC) announced on 19 June 2013 that it upheld the appeal from the HPVS‐SST consortium, while disqualifying the Salini‐Impregilo joint venture based on its alleged failure to meet the following tender requirements:
—
demonstrating that the experience of the specialists being put forward for the project manager and assistant project manager positions was equivalent to a master's degree in ‘Transport construction/Engineering’;
—
 demonstrating the necessary work experience for the position of health and safety coordinator.
The company maintains that it supplied all the necessary documentation to prove the requirements were met.
In light of the above, can the Commission answer the following questions:
1.
Is it true that the infrastructure in question will be constructed using funds coming from the European Union’s budget?
2.
If this is the case and given the suspected illegitimate nature of the decisions made by the Bulgarian Agency for Roads and Infrastructure (ARI) on this matter, what audit checks does the Commission intend to carry out to ensure that European funds are used properly, efficiently and effectively?
3.
Furthermore, does the Commission believe that the European directives on public procurement have been infringed, given that the principles of transparency and non-discrimination seem to have been disregarded?
4.
Finally, does it also believe that European law on professional qualifications has been infringed, given the refusal to recognise the specialists who have all the necessary attributes?

titles: Foam and sludge - Torre Calderina
details: Question for written answer E-003347/2017to the CommissionRule 130Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
party: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
content:
Acquedotto Pugliese is planning to build an underwater outfall to discharge wastewater from the treatment plants serving the localities of Bisceglie, Corato, Molfetta, Ruvi di Puglia, and Terlizzi. 
This project is also considered necessary in order to ensure that wastewater is conveyed to its final destination, even when there is no demand for irrigation.
The underwater outfall will not contain the impacts on the ‘Posidonieto San Vito — Barletta’ SCI protected area (IT9120009), given the adverse effect on water quality likely to result from the possible spread of high pollution loads spilling into the receiving water body.
On 24 February 2017, a large quantity of foam and sludge was found to have accumulated at the outflow point of the treatment plant near Torre Calderina. In addition to the foam left at the waterline, there was a characteristic odour of surfactants. Acquedotto Pugliese says that the incident could have been caused by unauthorised non-compliant wastewater discharges downstream from the plant’s discharge point.
What steps will the Commission take to protect the area in accordance with Directive 35/2004/EC on environmental liability with regard to the prevention and remedying of environmental damage? Will it also ascertain whether the project has complied with Article 6 of Directive 92/43/EEC?

titles: Economic impact of the Commission proposal on GMO cultivation on competitiveness in the farming industry, food prices and raw material imports
details: Question for written answer E-006496/2011to the CommissionRule 117Sergio Berlato (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
The report by DG SANCO on the socioeconomic implications of GMO cultivation states that growers of genetically modified maize in Spain, Portugal, Romania and the Czech Republic have, on average, recorded yields up to 12.5 % higher than conventional farmers. The report also states that genetically modified soybeans cultivated in Romania until 2007 generated a 31 % increase in productivity compared with the conventional variety. 
Prior to drawing up the proposal for a revision of Directive 2001/18/EC on the release of GMOs, did the Commission consider its likely economic impact?

Can the Commission provide a rough estimate of the impact such a proposal is likely to have on the following: 
1.
competitiveness and freedom of choice in the farming industry, in particular in the area of maize production;
2.
food prices for consumers, in particular the price of maize-based foods or foods made using maize or maize-based products;
3.
total imports from third countries of GMO raw materials, particularly soybeans and maize?

titles: End-of-waste specific criteria for aggregates, paper, glass, plastics, metal, tyres and textiles
details: WRITTEN QUESTION E-0669/10by Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)to the Commission
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
Directive 2008/98/EC(1) of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 November 2008 on waste and repealing certain directives was published in the Official Journal of the European Union (L 312) on 22 November 2008. The directive must be transposed within two years of its entry into force.

Article 6 of the directive provides for the possibility of an end to ‘waste’ status if the waste has undergone a recovery, including recycling, providing that:
—
the substance or object is commonly used for specific purposes;
—
a market or demand exists for such a substance or object;
—
the substance or object fulfils the technical requirements for the specific purposes and meets the existing legislation and standards applicable to products; and
—
the use of the substance or object will not lead to overall adverse environmental or human health impacts.
The directive clearly states that the development of end-of-waste specific criteria for aggregates, paper, glass, plastics, metal, tyres and textiles should be considered.
Have the criteria applicable to these categories of waste been drawn up?
(1)OJ L 312, 22.11.2008, p. 3.

titles: Call by the Commission to dismiss the Chief Public Prosecutor of Bulgaria
details: Question for written answer P-015410/2015to the CommissionRule 130Emil Radev (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
At the start of November, the Bulgarian website Bivol published recordings of a series of conversations between the judges Vladimira Yaneva and Rumyana Chenalova in which references are made to violation of the law. Both judges have since been removed from office and the public prosecutor has brought charges against them. It is clear from the checks conducted that the recordings were not made using any lawfully‐implemented investigative means and were done without proper authorisation, which is an offence, while at the same time it has not been established whether the content of the recordings are authentic or if these were doctored. The public prosecutor and Supreme Judicial Council have been conducting enquiries into the events.
On 25 November 2015, it was claimed on the website Mediapool (http://www.mediapool.bg/ek-nastoya-za-obektivna-proverka-na-yanevageit-i-otteglyane-na-glavniya-prokuror-news242277.html) that the Commission would like the Chief Public Prosecutor of Bulgaria and other judicial figures mentioned in the recordings removed from office. On 26 November 2015, the website (http://www.mediapool.bg/ek-za-razsledvaneto-na-yanevageit-i-vremennoto-otteglyane-na-tsatsarov-news242318.html) showed correspondence on this matter from an unnamed Commission official 
Can the Commission state, in the light of the above:
1.
Whether it wanted the Chief Public Prosecutor of Bulgaria, or any of the other persons mentioned in the unauthorised recordings, removed from office? 
2.
Whether any Commission official has stated that view and, if so, who?
3.
Whether the Commission official in question was duly authorised to make such a statement, or whether this has been incorrectly reported?

titles: Nazi souvenirs from Estonia
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert (ALDE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
content:
In recent years I have repeatedly been contacted by Netherlands nationals who, while staying in Estonia, have been confronted with a wide range of products (‘souvenirs’) which, to put it mildly, awaken very uncomfortable memories of the Second World War and the Nazi regime. In several places, including the capital Tallinn, items including the following were on sale:
—

SS officers' caps and helmets,
—

red arm-bands with swastikas,
—

photos of Adolf Hitler,
—

matchboxes with images of the Third Reich,
—

souvenir t-shirts with pictures of Adolf Hitler,
—

Nazi German officers’ medals.

It is often argued that these are ‘collectors’ items’. However, it is undoubtedly true that they also appeal to people who find such ‘collectors’ items’ attractive, for whatever reason. The fact that the sale of such items is not banned in Estonia rightly gives rise to incomprehension and revulsion among many people. At any rate it prompts me to put the following questions:
1.

Is the Commission aware of the sale of the abovementioned items?
2.

Does the Commission agree that such items fly in the face of everything the EU stands for, in particular the principles of freedom, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms (given that they symbolise totally opposite values)? If not, why not?
3.

Is the Commission prepared to raise this state of affairs with the Estonian authorities in order to put a stop to it? If not, why not?
4.

Can the Commission state whether similar products are also on sale in other EU countries? If so, can it state which countries, and whether any action has been taken against these countries?

titles: Pernicious effects of liberalisation and deregulation in the electric sector
details: Question for written answer E-002204/2015to the CommissionRule 130João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), Neoklis Sylikiotis (GUE/NGL)
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
In several countries, the liberalisation of the electric sector has patently failed to achieve the stated objectives. In fact, electricity prices for final consumers — families as well as enterprises — have increased rather than decreased, contrary to what had been promised.
The United States, Canada, Australia, Sweden, Norway, Peru, the Dominican Republic and Brazil are examples of countries in which deregulation in the electrical sector has led to significant increases in electricity prices. The experiences in some of these countries have been used as case studies in academic work.
Specifically, the ending of vertical integration and the segmentation of the production and distribution chains, imposed by the EU, has had the effect of disaggregating production costs and of transferring to final consumers costs that prior to liberalisation had in each country been absorbed by the profits of a single company. The result is increased profits for large economic groups in the electric sector at the expense of families and enterprises, which instead face heavily increased energy bills.
1. Have studies been conducted on the consequences of the deregulation of the electrical sector in Member States, and, if so, what is the Commission’s assessment of these studies?
2. Taking into account the evidence of the damage caused by liberalisation, and in particular the damage caused by the ending of vertical integration, is the Commission considering the possibility of reviewing such policies and options as they are being pursued in the EU?

titles: Controls in the Member States on the transport of laboratory animals
details: Question for written answer E-006898/2015to the CommissionRule 130Dominique Bilde (NI), Sophie Montel (NI)
party: Non-attached Members
content:
The transport of laboratory animals (by road, sea or air) is regulated and subject to official controls under the same conditions as that of other animals by Regulation (EC) No 1/2005 on the protection of animals during transport and related operations (such as, for example, the preparation, caging, loading or unloading of animals).
This regulation stipulates that animal safety must be ensured, that the animals must be handled without resorting to violence or methods liable to cause unnecessary suffering and that rest, watering, feeding and care breaks must be respected in the light of the needs of each animal species. 
1. What is the Commission’s assessment of the information transmitted by Member States and will it carry out controls?
2. How are these controls organised? How and by what organisation are they carried out?
3. In case of breaches, including the use of violence, what penalties and follow-up action has the Commission provided for to remedy the situation?

titles: Assistance for children with haemophilia in the ex-Soviet Union
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Cristiana Muscardini (UEN) to the Commission
party: Union for Europe of the Nations Group
content:
The situation of children with haemophilia is particularly serious in the ex-Soviet Union because of the scarcity of clotting factors, which are vital for treatment of the illness. None of them can afford this type of therapy due to the high costs of, on average, EUR 500 per month. They suffer pointlessly, confined to wheelchairs due to their articular haematoma, regularly hospitalised for transfusions and isolated from their peers, since they cannot play.
Public, private and voluntary bodies, in Italy, and of course also in other European countries, provide assistance to the children through consignments of clotting factors in the knowledge that they will not be enough to cover all their needs. The different voluntary programmes are not coordinated and sometimes come up against bureaucratic obstacles in relation to customs and health regulations.

Therefore, will the Commission:
1.
promote the establishment of an information network at Community level of the local centres of blood products in order that at least a small quantity of clotting factors are distributed to the ex-Soviet countries?
2.
call on governments, and in particular health ministers, to undertake to coordinate financial assistance for the collection and authorised despatch of clotting factors in cooperation with the health minister of the Russian Federation?
3.
undertake to offer its services for humanitarian aid in terms of monitoring requirements and coordinating the authorised despatch of clotting factors in cooperation with the Russian authorities?

titles: Demonstrating against the EU becomes a criminal offence in Greece
details: Question for written answer E-012684/2013to the CommissionRule 117Mara Bizzotto (EFD)
party: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
content:
On Thursday 24 October 2013, Article 458a was inserted into the Greek Penal Code. Entitled ‘Violations of EU regulations’, the article provides for a maximum two-year jail sentence for anyone who acts against European structures by resisting, opposing or expressing disagreement with EU sanctions, governments or representatives.
1. Is the Commission aware of this situation? 
2. Have other Member States incorporated similar provisions in their penal codes?
3. Does the Commission believe that respect for the European institutions can be made a requirement under criminal law?

titles: Adaptation of Directive 92/43/EEC on natural habitats and wild fauna and flora
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Maartje van Putten(PSE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Party of European Socialists
content:
On 28 May 1997 the Commission presented a proposal for a Directive adapting to technical and scientific progress Directive 92/43/EEC on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora (COM(97)195 final). The proposal aimed, according to point 7 of the Explanatory Statement, to ‘remove the habitat sub-types (e.g. "grey dunes") which are now described in the Interpretation Manual EUR 15 version'. The proposal was adopted by the Council on 27 October 1997 (Directive 97/62/EEC (1).
1.   How is it being ensured that each of the specific habitat subtypes which were included in the original classification of certain habitats (Annex I to Directive 92/43/EEC (2)) is adequately represented in the Natura 2000 network?
2.   Leaving aside the previous question, are the Member States also required under Directive 92/43/EEC to designate a selection of areas such that sufficient variation within the different kinds of habitat is ensured?
3.   What is the legal status of the "Interpretation Manual of European Habitats, version EUR 15", which is referred to in the proposal and in the Annex to Directive 97/62/EEC, in comparison with an annex to a directive enacted by the Council?
(1)OJ L 305, 8.11.1997, p. 42.(2)OJ L 206, 22.7.1992, p. 7.

titles: EU health and food safety inspections in Western Sahara
details: Question for written answer E-000809/2017to the CommissionRule 130Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE), Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE), Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE), Max Andersson (Verts/ALE), Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE), Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE), Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL), João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), Takis Hadjigeorgiou (GUE/NGL), Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL), Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL), Kostadinka Kuneva (GUE/NGL), Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL), Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
In her answer to Written Question E-004000/2016, the Vice-President/High Representative stated that three of the four audits planned in Morocco in 2016 by the Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG SANTE) had been postponed and that the remaining audit (2016-8915) would not visit the Sahrawi-occupied territories.
On 21 December 2016, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) ruled, in Case C-104/16 P — Council v Front Polisario, that the Association and Liberalisation Agreements concluded between the EU and Morocco are not applicable to Western Sahara.
According to DG SANTE’s website, four audits have been planned in Morocco in 2017 (2017-6227; 2017-6220; 2017-6190; 2017-6128).
Can the Commission confirm that, in accordance with the findings of the ECJ in Case C-104/16 P, the Health and Food Audits and Analysis service will not visit Moroccan infrastructures or other Moroccan entities located in the Sahrawi-occupied territories?
Can it clarify which national authorities it considers competent to deliver the food and safety certificates for products originating in Western Sahara, as required under EU legislation?
[Question supported by Members other than the author(s)(1)]
(1)Question supported by Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL), João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)

titles: VP/HR - Recent designations of media outlets as 'foreign agents' in the Russian Federation
details: Question for written answer E-007615/2017to the CommissionRule 130Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
party: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
content:
On 5 December 2017, Russia’s Ministry of Justice designated nine US Government-funded media outlets, including Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, as ‘foreign agents’, a move that could complicate their news-gathering operations in Russia.
In his observations submitted to the European Court of Human Rights on a group of cases which challenge the so-called ‘Law on Foreign Agents’ before this Court, the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights, Nils Muižnieks, stated that:
‘The application of this law has had a chilling effect on the work of civil society organisations in the Russian Federation and has considerably interfered with the rights to freedom of association and freedom of expression of many non-commercial organisations and human rights defenders, sometimes with severe consequences. Apart from the difficulties in securing funding, such groups and the persons working in them have been subjected to ostracism, harassment, and even physical attacks’.
What does the VP/HR envisage doing in order to urge the Russian Government not to allow this to stifle free speech and editorial independence?

titles: Researchers' right to inventions
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Astrid Thors (ELDR) to the Commission
party: Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party
content:
A constant source of complaint from the Commission is the low number of applications for patents in Europe compared with the USA. The Community patent has been vaunted as a remedy even though it probably does not promote European inventions particularly. A more compelling reason for fewer patents may be the rules on the right to inventions made at universities. In the USA, it is the universities which hold the right to inventions; in Europe, it is the researchers. Often, however, they lack the financial resources and knowledge of the law to exploit inventions. This issue has been touched on in some of the Commission's most recent documents on innovation and biotechnology.
Has the Commission carried out any comparative study of university researchers' exploitation of their inventions? How different is the legislation in the various countries? Does the Commission intend to take any measures, within its sphere of competence, in this area? How many countries are in the process of reviewing this matter? (Germany?).

titles: ECJ insurance ruling
details: Question for written answer P-002818/2011to the CommissionRule 117Sajjad Karim (ECR)
party: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
content:
On 1 March 2011, the European Court of Justice delivered a ruling(1) negating a specific derogation inserted into the law of the European Union by the European Parliament and Council permitting premiums and annuities offered by companies to differ on the basis of gender where demonstrable variations in insurable risk arose due to a person’s gender.
Actuarial evidence exists showing male drivers on average have more car accidents than female drivers. Similarly, women benefit from higher life expectancy than men. Logically, this means the risk profile of a male driver or a female seeking health insurance will differ — a fact which the European institutions explicitly recognised in their approach in Article 5(2) of EU Directive 2004/113/EC.
As a direct result of the decision of the Court to ignore the express will of the Parliament and Council, the European insurance and reinsurance federation CEA expects that consumers will face significant additional costs; the Association of British Insurers, however, actually estimates that this decision will reinforce price discrimination, with women drivers under 26 in the UK facing a 25 % rise in car insurance rates, with a 10 % drop in rates for men.
What concrete steps will the Commission take to address this issue, which will penalise consumers — both male and female — and harm the European insurance and pensions industry?
(1)Judgment in Case C‑236/09 Association belge des Consommateurs Test-Achats ASBL and Others v Conseil des ministres.

titles: Exports of fish containing dioxins
details: Question for written answer E-005559/2011to the CommissionRule 117Nikolaos Chountis (GUE/NGL)
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006 sets maximum levels for certain pollutants in food. Some species of fish from the Baltic contain high levels of dioxins and dioxin-like polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and are therefore not safe for consumption. A derogation from the regulation allows the sale of certain fish species from the Baltic with higher dioxin levels in two Member States, Sweden and Finland, provided that the necessary steps are taken to ensure that such fish and fish products are not sold in other Member States.
According to an article in the Swedish newspaper Göteborgsposten, there are signs that, despite the ban, fish with dioxin levels exceeding the maximum limits has been exported to other Member States. A Swedish fish exporter has also admitted to exporting to France 300 kilograms of salmon contaminated with dioxins.
1. Why were Sweden and Finland given a derogation in the regulation? Does the Commission intend to end this derogation?
2. Can it confirm that contaminated fish from the Baltic have been exported to other Member States?
3. What mechanisms are there to prevent illegal fish exports?

titles: VP/HR - Situation of the English-speaking community in Cameroon
details: Question for written answer E-000660/2018to the CommissionRule 130Isabella De Monte (S&D), Herbert Dorfmann (PPE)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content:
Strife broke out between the English‐ and French-speaking communities in Cameroon in October 2017. Eight people were killed and several others injured in clashes between the army and protesters in the English-speaking area. The English-speaking community makes up a fifth of Cameroon’s population and has for some time been suffering discrimination at the hands of the French-speaking majority community and of the French-speaking Government, which has previously been accused of corruption. Under the Constitution of the Federal Republic of Cameroon the regions used to enjoy wide-ranging autonomy, and French and English were both official languages. The English-speaking separatist movement, which has continued the protests, has been calling for a declaration of independence in order to bring about a complete secession, thereby creating the ‘Republic of Ambazonia’. 
In the light of these serious events: 
—
Is the High Representative aware of the abovementioned discrimination? What will she do to protect the English-speaking community in Cameroon, not least in view of the fact that the Cameroonian Army has resorted to shooting? 
—
How does she intend to respond to the possibility of secession and a self-declared ‘Republic of Ambazonia’?

titles: Passenger rail services between Britain and continental Europe
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Kenneth Coates(GUE/NGL) to the Commission
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left
content: What, if any, European funding has gone to support Eurostar rail services? What is the Commission's view of the long delay in introducing, and recent reports of the possible abandonment of, direct Eurostar services between the East Midlands and the North of England and continental Europe?

titles: Support by the Commission for vulnerable girls in developing countries
details: Question for written answer E-006452/2011to the CommissionRule 117Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE), Véronique Mathieu (PPE), Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE), Norbert Neuser (S&D), Françoise Castex (S&D), Antonyia Parvanova (ALDE), Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
In developing countries, 70 000 girls between the ages of 15 and 19 die every year due to pregnancy-related complications or during childbirth: this is a major cause of death for girls in that age group. Moreover, one in seven girls marries before her 15th birthday. These girls therefore become more likely to get pregnant than unmarried girls and less likely to go to school, and will have a lower income as adults, with severe consequences for their own lives and for the economic, human and social development of their countries.
Against this background, what efforts is the Commission making to support and protect vulnerable girls in the EU's partner countries in the developing world?
Does the Commission believe it should encourage capacity-building on the part of local administrations with a view to better monitoring of the implementation of the laws on age limits for marriage?
What is the Commission doing to assess the gender-specific impact of financed programmes in support of this target group, e.g. with regard to accessibility for young women and girls and social acceptance?
How is the EU promoting the health rights of girls in its policy dialogue with beneficiary countries and in international forums?
How are the specific needs of girls concerning prevention of unwanted pregnancies and better access to modern contraceptives reflected in the Commission’s programmes under the DCI and EDF?
Given that there are no specific financial programmes or funding envelopes in place to support vulnerable girls in developing countries, is the Commission planning to propose earmarking explicit funding for this target group under the next multiannual financial framework?

titles: VP/HR - Peace agreement in Mali
details: Question for written answer E-010316/2015to the CommissionRule 130Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
• On 20 June a peace agreement was signed in Mali and ratified by all the affected parties in that country, under the supervision of the High Representative and the EU’s Commissioner for International Cooperation and Development
This peace deal is intimately related to an EU development aid programme for Mali, which will run over the 2014-2020 period, in exchange for the respect of the parties implicated in the peace agreement.
On the basis of this agreement the EU and Mali’s Government have committed themselves to work on various priority areas over the next 6 years. 
What expectations does the European Union have in regard to this peace agreement? 
Does the High Representative intend to visit the country soon to check on the progress and development of the agreement?

titles: Structural Funds in Italy

2.
publish the state of commitments and payments made by Italy for the 1994-1999 programming period?

state its views on the current situation?

state whether there is still a possibility that some funds will be diverted to other countries whose utilization procedures have proved to be more efficient?

titles: Length of the ECVAM Director's term of office
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Philippe De Coene(PSE) and Anne Van Lancker(PSE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Party of European Socialists
content:
The term of office of the Director of the European Centre for the Validation of Alternative Methods (ECVAM) has recently been renewed. The usual term is five years, but this time an extension of only two years has been granted.
Limiting the term of office in this way will seriously jeopardize any research that is launched during the period concerned. Many research projects can obviously not be completed in such a time, and two years is also too short to draw any well-founded long-term conclusions.
Scientific centres will not attach much credibility to the ECVAM when they realize that the Director has barely two years to carry out his research.
Does the Commission not agree that it makes scientific sense to grant a full term of five years? What are the reasons for choosing a shorter term?

titles: The EED Directive on radiator heat meters and the method of calculation of consumption
details: Question for written answer E-003997/12by Jarosław Leszek Wałęsa (PPE)to the Commission
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
I would like to address the provision in the fourth paragraph of Article 8(1) of the proposal for a directive on Energy Efficiency which imposes an obligation to install heat meters, and in multi-family buildings, additional individual heat consumption meters. If the installation of individual heat consumption meters is not technically feasible, according to the wording of the directive, individual heat cost allocators should be used.
Is the Commission aware of the additional costs associated with transposing the cited Directive into national law, in terms of requiring the owners and managers of multi-family buildings to install individual heat meters?
Is the Commission aware of the fact that the provisions in the directive may significantly increase the operating costs of premises in multi-family buildings?
In addition, the effectiveness of individual heat consumption meters and the method of calculating the costs of heat consumption in the form of heat cost allocators are questionable. As indicated in the research and opinions of many specialists in this field, foreign meters and the proposed form of heat cost allocators often do not work in multi-family building conditions (in particular in old buildings), showing extremely different heat consumption for apartments in the same building with the same degree of heating. This is the result of both the transfer of heat through the partition walls of buildings, and its emission from nodal heating systems. That is why the following question is of key importance: in formulating the cited provision of the directive, was the Commission aware of the specific differences in housing management among the various Member States?

titles: Maryam Bahreman's detention in Iran
details: Question for written answer E-006356/2011to the CommissionRule 117Pino Arlacchi (S&D), María Muñiz De Urquiza (S&D), Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE), Gabriele Albertini (PPE), Fiorello Provera (EFD), Potito Salatto (PPE), Joanna Senyszyn (S&D), Britta Thomsen (S&D), Jaroslav Paška (EFD), Anne Delvaux (PPE), Norica Nicolai (ALDE), Charles Tannock (ECR), Marita Ulvskog (S&D), Marietta Giannakou (PPE), Giommaria Uggias (ALDE), Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE), Nicole Sinclaire (NI), Zuzana Roithová (PPE), Alexandra Thein (ALDE), Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), Baroness Sarah Ludford (ALDE), Boris Zala (S&D), Vincent Peillon (S&D), Sari Essayah (PPE), Mariya Nedelcheva (PPE), Frieda Brepoels (Verts/ALE), Franziska Keller (Verts/ALE), Harlem Désir (S&D), Ivo Vajgl (ALDE), Robert Rochefort (ALDE), Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE), Paul Murphy (GUE/NGL), Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
According to the information received from several NGOs, the women’s rights activist Maryam Bahreman was arrested on 11 May 2011 in Shiraz. Security force officers from the Intelligence Ministry went to her house with a detention order. They reportedly arrested her on the charge of ‘action against national security’.
Maryam Bahreman is a social activist and a member of ‘One million signatures’. She has been active in promoting women’s rights for several years. Her lawyer disclosed that she has been subjected to an interrogation relating to her human rights activities and in particular to her recent attendance at the 55th session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women conference in New York in March of this year. The judicial procedure against her will start only after the interrogation has finished. She is at serious risk: torture or other ill-treatment of detainees in Iran is common, and is often used to force them to make ‘confessions’, often televised, which can be used as evidence against them in court, in violation of the prohibition of torture and Article 14 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), to which Iran is a state party.
1. Is the Commission aware of the Bahreman case? What steps does the Commission intend to adopt in response to these serious violations of freedom of expression and association?
2. What preventive measures will the Commission take to protect the health of Maryam Bahreman and all human rights activists in Iran also in the light of the Declaration on Human Rights Defenders adopted on 9 December 1998 by the United Nations General Assembly?

titles: Support for offshore mining
details: Question for written answer E-004267/2016to the CommissionRule 130Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content:
In the face of dwindling land-based deposits and the risk of supplies of some raw materials drying up, attention is turning to offshore multi-metal deposits containing many of the metals that are regarded as strategic raw materials. The Commission has identified 20 raw materials that are of critical importance to the development of highly advanced technologies. The risk of supplies of those materials drying up is being heightened by the limited use being made of recycled materials and the small scale of substitution efforts. Mineral scarcity is a real cause of concern for the EU. Although the EU is self-sufficient in construction minerals, of which it is a major producer, it accounts for only 3% of world production of metallic minerals. The EU as a whole is dependent on imports of metallic minerals and the metals needed for high-tech products. In many cases (doping metals being a prime example), all of the EU's needs are met by imports, and in the case of metals required for high-tech products the EU's dependency on imports may be regarded as critical, in view of those metals' economic value and the high supply risks associated with them. 
1. What support does the Commission plan to provide over the coming years for seabed and ocean floor mineral exploration and exploitation?
2. Does the Commission intend to draw up a roadmap for the development of marine and ocean areas that will reap the benefits of innovative forms of exploitation of natural resources and raw materials?

content:
In March 2016, following the decision by the Council of the EU to suspend direct financial support to the Burundian Government, including budgetary support, the EU undertook to review the arrangements for the payment of Burundian soldiers in the African Union’s mission to Somalia (Amisom). If the information proves correct, what position will the EU take to ensure a coherent approach and avoid any collusion with or support for the Burundian authorities?

titles: Notification procedure for additional aid of EUR 30 million for Kassel-Calden airport
details: Question for written answer E-4765/2010to the CommissionRule 117Sabine Wils (GUE/NGL)
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
In its notification on construction work at Kassel-Calden airport, the Commission stresses that the project could possibly lead to night flights banned from Frankfurt/Main being transferred to Calden. The same thing could also be done with night flights from Cologne/Bonn and Düsseldorf.
It should be noted that the legally binding planning permit allows for only four flights per night — two take-offs and two landings —, as the Administrative Appeals Court (Verwaltungsgerichtshof) of Kassel explicitly confirmed in its judgment of 21 August 2009. Furthermore, night flights for freight aircraft are to be concentrated in Leipzig; night flights from Kassel-Calden would be in breach of this guideline.
It would appear that the government of the state of Hesse is misleading us by presenting the expansion of Kassel-Calden as a way of creating an alternative airport to relieve pressure on other airports.
Did the government of Hesse state that Calden would be an alternative airport for night flights in the notification request or did this information come from the Commission?

titles: Extension of Adamas harbour, Island of Milos, Cyclades, Greece
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Alexander de Roo (Verts/ALE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
By joint order 69269 of 30 March 1998 the Minister of the Environment, Regional Planning and Public Works and the Minister of the Merchant Maríne of Greece approved the above projected works. In November 1999 the Greek Government decided to go ahead with the work which was described as harbour works in order to benefit from Community funding. In fact the works are fundamentally transforming the urban and regional planning of the island by embankment of the entire length of the marine parade where the road runs along the beach, thus creating carriageways and additional areas allowing various bars and restaurants to set up tables beside the sea.
The environmental impact assessment does not seem to have been carried out in accordance with the relevant law (Law 1650/1986, Directive 85/337/EEC(1) and joint ministerial orders Nos 69269/5387/1990). The Council of State, to which an appeal was made on 11 November 1999 for suspension of the works, rejected the appeal on 18 January 2000 under a recently adopted provision, Article 35 of Law 2721/1999; the President of the Fifth Chamber of the Council of State merely invoked the concept of "public interest", without giving any reasons, and thus authorised resumption of the works(2). An appeal to annul the administration's decision was also lodged on 8 November 1999. When considering this appeal the Council of State deemed it admissible and thus contradicted itself by casting doubt on the public-interest argument advanced in its judgment of 18 January 2000. However, the appeal has been pending since it was lodged, and this has enabled the promoters of the works to complete them.
The possibility of widespread application of the above provision under Law 2721/1999 is dangerously restricting Greek citizens' right to temporary protection by the courts and is likely to allow the completion of works financed from Community funds that will have irreversible environmental consequences.
Can the Commission consider the above question and take the necessary measures with regard to the Greek authorities to ensure compliance with Community law, particularly the rules on environmental impact assessments?
Does the Commission not consider that there is a need to ask the Greek authorities to refund the Community funds granted for this project, if Community rules are not being complied with?
What, in the Commission's view, would be the risks caused by widespread application of the above provision under Law 2721/1999?
(1)OJ L 175, 5.7.1985. The assessment provides no details of the works or environment affected, no assessment of the consequences in all their possible forms, no detail of proposed pollution prevention, reduction or compensation measures, no consideration of advantages and disadvantages, no justification according to purely environmental criteria of the solution chosen and no analysis of alternative solutions to protect the Bay of Milos and its eco-system, the second largest natural bay in the Mediterranean. The Island of Milos is already severely affected by mineral extraction activities and plans to extend such activities, which are seriously affecting the environment (see Written Question E-0318/2000). The inclusion of the region on the west coast of Milos in the Natura 2000 network, under Directive 92/43/EEC, published in OJ L 206, 22.7.1992) is being held up by the local authorities who are mainly responsible for the works concerned.(2)The main reason for the works is to enlarge the area available for restaurants and bars.

titles: Study on the concentration of nicotine and benzene in the hospitality sector
details: Question for written answer E-010838/2010to the CommissionRule 117Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE)
party: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance
content:
The recent study ‘Exposure to benzene as a carcinogen in environmental tobacco smoke in the hospitality sector’, carried out by Barcelona's Public Health Agency, looked at the concentration of nicotine and benzene in 37 bars in the city of Barcelona. An average concentration of 6.16 micrograms of benzene per cubic metre of air was measured in the bars, while Directive 2008/50/EC on ambient air quality and cleaner air sets an outdoor limit value of 5 μg/m3 of benzene. Despite the progress made in Spanish legislation with the introduction of anti-smoking measures in Law 28/2005, Spain is far from meeting the objectives of the Green Paper ‘Towards a Europe free from tobacco smoke’, the Council Recommendation on smoke-free environments adopted in 2009, or the guidelines from the WHO Conference on Tobacco Control. In the light of this, Law 28/2005 is currently being amended to strengthen the areas in which progress has been less noticeable.
What is the Commission's view of the data in the above study?
Does the Commission think that the measures currently applied by the Spanish Government are sufficient to combat smoking?
Does the Commission think that values should be laid down to limit these harmful smoking-related substances in public places?

titles: The Commission's use of private consultants
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Arlene McCarthy(PSE) to the Commission
party: Group of the Party of European Socialists
content:
As part of the reform of the Structural Funds, the Commission intends to decentralise further the operation of Structural Fund programmes, withdrawing from the day-to-day management of programmes in favour of a stronger Commission "policing" role. During the 1994-1999 programme, how many consultants has the Commission engaged in the administration of the following programmes?

What has been the total cost, and what percentage of the programmes allocations does it represent:
-
across the EU as a whole,

titles: Resin tapping
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Sylviane Ainardi(GUE/NGL) to the Commission
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left
content:
There continues to be a major shortage of pine resin products in Europe. Unfortunately, owing to falling prices and a lack of encouragement, production of pine resin has been abandoned in many areas, such as the Landes region of France.
A new resin tapping process (the 'closed vessel' technique) was developed recently. This process is more efficient and enables turpentine to be obtained by decantation, together with crystallized resin. A mobile distillation unit is then used for on-site conversion of the crystallized resin into gum rosin and turpentine. Trials are currently being conducted.
Is the Commission aware of these new techniques, and does it intend to provide encouragement in the form of financial aid with a view to reviving pine resin production in forest regions such as the Landes?

titles: Compatibility of German road-toll scheme with EU law
