2. If so, is the proposed scheme compatible with EC law?
3. Does the scheme not clearly violate the principle of non-discrimination inasmuch as there are explicit plans to introduce, at the same time, a discount on vehicle tax at precisely the level of the toll charge, so that, in effect, the owners of vehicles registered in Germany will not have to pay the toll?

titles: Inconsistency between Council Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 and double taxation treaties
details: Question for written answer E-003241/2020to the CommissionRule 138Jeroen Lenaers (PPE), Kris Peeters (PPE)
party: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
content: In the wake of the corona crisis, which has forced many border workers into working from home or into temporary unemployment, inconsistencies have emerged between the provisions of double taxation treaties and those of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004. Taxing rights are established in line with double taxation treaties, while compulsory insurance and contribution arrangements are laid down by Regulation (EC) No 883/2004. Under the coronavirus provisions, social security benefits and contributions for border workers are still payable in the country of employment, while income tax is levied in the country of residence. This inconsistency is also a structural problem, given that income and benefit tax arrangements for border workers, posted workers and international transport workers are governed by around 600 different double taxation treaties between Member States, while compulsory insurance is governed by Regulation (EC) No 883/2004.1. Does the Commission acknowledge the inconsistencies between the allocation provisions of the double taxation treaties and those of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 and the need to resolve them?2. Is the Commission prepared to set up a working group of taxation and social security experts to recommend ways of improving coordination and ensuring greater consistency between the allocation provisions of the double taxation treaties and the corresponding provisions of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004?

titles: Castration of piglets
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Bart Staes (Verts/ALE), Kathalijne Maria Buitenweg (Verts/ALE), David Hammerstein (Verts/ALE), Paulo Casaca (PSE), Karin Scheele (PSE), John Bowis (PPE-DE) and Neil Parish (PPE-DE) to the Commission
party: Socialist Group in the European Parliament
content:
The results of a special Eurobarometer survey about the attitude of the European citizens to the welfare of farmed animals (published in June 2006) show that a minority of the population thinks that the welfare of pigs is unsatisfactory. One of the elements that surely contributes to a lower welfare of piglets is castration without anaesthesia. The EFSA-report ‘Welfare aspects of the castration of piglets’ (EFSA Journal (2004) 91, 1-18, page 18), says that this is painful and for newborn piglets it is even worse. In 1997 the Scientific Committee on Animal Health and Animal Welfare concluded that castration causes severe pain and harm that, where possible, ‘should be prevented’.

At this moment, over 10 years later, the EU still allows the castration of piglets up to the age of seven days without anaesthetic. Although the European Parliament approved this in a resolution on 12 October 2006, this is obviously not reconcilable with the official policy of the Commission that recognises that animals are sentient beings (http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/welfare/index_en.htm).

Why has the Commission, in spite of convincing scientific evidence and a broad public consensus on the fact that pigs deserve better treatment, not yet taken measures to ensure that farmers abandon the castration of piglets — whatever their age may be — without anaesthesia?

titles: Independent growth forecasts

titles: Distortion of competition as a result of the low costs of employing Polish construction workers not covered by a collective agreement in the Member States of the European Union
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Erik Meijer (GUE/NGL) to the Commission
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left
content:
1. Can the Commission confirm that the social dialogue introduced in Poland in connection with the adoption of the "acquis communautaire" of the European Union involves discussions being held once a year by the Polish government with national umbrella organisations of employees and employers, that these informal discussions do not lead to agreements and that they are not followed up by discussions between employees' and employers' organisations operating in individual sectors?
2. Can the Commission also confirm that there are no national or regional collective agreements in the construction sector in Poland, which includes housing, commercial and industrial buildings, roads, bridges and dams, but only agreements at the level of individual companies or their local branches?
3. Is the Commission aware that Polish construction workers are being squeezed out in their own country by Ukrainians who work for lower pay, and that this is encouraging Poles to look for work on building projects in the existing Member States of the EU, primarily in Germany where, following the completion of a number of major projects, there is a high level of unemployment in the construction sector, and in Austria, Finland and Sweden?
4. Is it attractive for employers to recruit Polish construction workers as they can in practice be employed on lower pay and less favourable conditions of employment than workers who have been resident for long time in the Member State concerned, insofar as they are not covered by a Polish collective agreement or by a collective agreement of the country where they are employed — provided that such an agreement has not been declared generally binding —, so that companies not belonging to an employers' organisation which is a contracting party to a collective agreement have no other obligations than to pay the minimum wage?
5. Does the Commission expect this problem to have been resolved by the end of the seven-year period following Poland's accession to the EU during which labour migration will be restricted, if at that time there are still no generally binding collective agreements in Poland and other Member States? If so, on what grounds? If not, what additional measures are needed in order to prevent workers from being recruited on the basis of low employment costs?
6. Is the Commission preparing measures with a view to including migrant workers in collective agreements?

titles: Forest fire prevention in the Prefecture of Attica
details: WRITTEN QUESTION E-4234/09by Stavros Lambrinidis (S-D), Maria Eleni Koppa (S-D), Anni Podimata (S-D), Georgios Stavrakakis (S-D), Kriton Arsenis (S-D), Chrysoula Paliadeli (S-D), Giorgos Papakonstantinou (S-D) and Sylvana Rapti (S-D)to the Council
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content:
Exactly two years after the tragic fires in Greece, history is unfortunately repeating itself: once again catastrophic fires have devastated the forests of northern and eastern Attica, thereby depriving the Prefecture of its few remaining green ‘lungs’.

Bearing in mind that in a communication of March 2009, the Commission had proposed a series of specific measures and mechanisms aimed at improving the Union’s prevention, readiness and response capabilities in the event of disasters, such as fires, and recognising the dramatic reduction in forest cover in southern Europe, will the Council say:
1.
How well has the European preventive mechanism worked and to what extent have existing anti-fire mechanisms been set in motion this summer in southern Europe, bearing in mind that according to latest estimates by the European Forest Fire Information System, up to the middle of this year (2009) 200 000 hectares had been burnt in EU Member States, that is some 20 000 hectares more than in 2008?
2.
Has any assessment been carried out of planned measures to create and operate a European training network to address disasters and for the early warning of the intervention and rehabilitation phases in the event of disasters, inter alia, through the Global Monitoring for the Environment and Security (GMES) initiative and the use of the European single emergency call number (112)?
3.
What progress has been made in the execution of projects in Greece for the 2007‑13 period under the European Regional Fund and the Cohesion Fund to prevent and address risks, in particular as regards the Operational Programme for the Environment (2007‑13) and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development as regards the restoration of forestry capacity and the introduction of preventive measures?
4.
How does it view the information contained in a recent WWF Greece report (July 2009) condemning the failure to include fire brigade and civil protection group volunteers in the Greek framework? How does it view the accusations made by the Association of Fire Brigade Officials regarding shortages of personnel, shortcomings in material and technical infrastructures and in the critical sector of prevention? What information is available about the take-up rate and the use of the available Community aid resources by Greece to carry out preventive measures in 2008‑09?

titles: Artificial distortion of competition - distribution cost charges
details: Question for written answer E-004162/2017to the CommissionRule 130Deirdre Clune (PPE)

Can the Commission indicate if it has made any progress on taking action on the above concerns, which appear to indicate a breach of the Code of Conduct for computerised reservation systems?

titles: Freezing the EU-Israel Partnership Agreement because of the war in Gaza
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Willy Meyer Pleite (GUE/NGL) to the Council
party: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
content:
The military offensive launched on 27 December against the Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip by the Israeli Government is Israel's most important military offensive since the Six Days War of 1967.

Since June 2007 the entire Palestinian population of Gaza, 1.5 million people, has been trapped there under an imposed blockade.

Before the June ceasefire came into force, the first half of 2008 had seen 420 Palestinians killed at the hands of Israeli troops, including some 80 children. During the same period, armed Palestinian groups killed 24 Israelis, including four children.

On 4 November, Israeli troops carried out an overland raid and several attacks in Gaza, resulting in the deaths of six Palestinian activists. This unilateral breaking of the truce by Israel led to the launching of dozens of Palestinian rocket attacks on nearby areas and villages in the south of Israel, without causing any victims or damage.

By the eighteenth day of a war which contravenes international criminal and humanitarian law, 900 people had been killed and 4 000 had been seriously wounded.

Given the tragic situation in which the civilian population find itself,

does the Council intend to freeze the EU‑Israel Partnership Agreement as long as Israel fails to comply with Article 2 thereof, whereby the Agreement is dependent on respect for human rights?

What steps is the Commission taking to find out the facts concerning this problem and to propose means by which the difficulties can be alleviated?

titles: Agreement by the Government of Spain to repeal the 2012 labour reform
details: Question for written answer E-003147/2020to the CommissionRule 138Dolors Montserrat (PPE)

content: Yesterday, the political parties that make up the Spanish Government (PSOE and Unidas Podemos) agreed with the radical left of the Basque Country (EH Bildu) to repeal the 2012 labour reform in full.The reform made it possible to reduce the number of unemployed persons by 1 788 092 between February 2013 and May 2018 and to create 2 765 000 jobs.At present, with the serious blow to the economy and employment brought about by the pandemic, we cannot dispense with a tool that has helped millions of Spanish families and now allows millions of employees to be covered by short-time working arrangements (ERTE) and thus avoiding being made redundant.In 2011, Spain accounted for one out of every two unemployed people in Europe and in 2018 Spain accounted for one out of every two new jobs created in Europe.Were the labour reform to fall, unemployment in Spain would soar and the economy would go bankrupt.In view of this, we would like to ask the European Commission the following:1. Does it view the 2012 labour reform positively?2. Does it consider that this reform should be repealed?3. What control mechanisms is the Commission using to ensure that Member States implement measures conducive to the creation of jobs and not to their destruction?

titles: Use of sniffer dogs against spread of foot-and-mouth disease virus from South Korea

FMD has again broken out in South Korea (on 30 April), just after the International Office of Epizootics (OIE) had officially declared the country free of the disease (simultaneously with the Netherlands, France and Ireland).

titles: On the use of the digital dividend
details: Question for written answer E-002565/2012to the CommissionRule 117Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
party: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
content:
Promoting the development of digital television, the European Parliament adopted a resolution in which it is recommended that EU Member States switch off analogue terrestrial television by 2013. Multiplexed digital streams allow a large proportion of the frequency spectrum to be freed up. Freed-up frequencies can be used by Internet, mobile phone and other service providers. More effective frequency use will contribute to reducing the digital divide: wireless broadband will be available in rural areas and it will be simpler for more citizens to satisfy various social, economic and cultural needs that are becoming increasingly dependent on new technologies.
One of the main projects of the second pillar of the strategy for the Baltic Sea Region is to ‘coordinate the use of the digital dividend’.
Can the Commission indicate what measures are being used to coordinate the use of the digital dividend so that it is used more effectively? How are companies being encouraged to provide broadband services in sparsely populated areas? What has been achieved in the area of developing models of enhanced Member State cooperation for multilateral coordination and market control?

titles: Completion of Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) project

titles: VP/HR - Nobel Peace laureate calls for caution regarding engagement with Iran
details: Question for written answer E-014273/13by Fiorello Provera (EFD), by Charles Tannock (ECR)to the Commission
party: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
content:
In early November 2013, Nobel Prize laureate Shirin Ebadi called for the USA and EU to ban Iran from using western satellites to broadcast what she described as Islamic Republic propaganda. Iran currently broadcasts programmes in more than a dozen languages around the globe via satellite. Ms Ebadi said that the government of Iran had to be prevented from using satellites and that such a ban would serve to shut off the ‘propaganda microphones of the government’. She also called for senior government officials to face travel bans and for those who have funds deposited with European and American banks to have their assets confiscated.
Ms Ebadi says she believed that President Hassan Rouhani would make changes once in power, but that nothing has changed. A spokesman for Iran’s mission to the UN, Alireza Miryousefi, has claimed that ‘Iran, especially after the election of President Rouhani, has put a new emphasis on the unwavering dedication towards the promotion and protection of all human rights inside and outside the country’.
Ms Ebadi notes, however, that according to the International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH), over 200 people, including four minors, were executed between 14 June and 1 October 2013. This is double the number of executions that took place in the same period in 2012. She has warned EU nations not to rush to restore ties with the government in Tehran without improvements to Iran’s human rights record.
1. What is the position of the Vice-President/High Representative regarding the Iranian Government’s use of European satellites to broadcast state-sponsored programmes?
2. What steps is the Vice-President/High Representative prepared to adopt to push for greater scrutiny of Iran’s human rights record?
3. In light of the number of executions which have taken place, what is the position of the Vice-President/High Representative regarding President Hassan Rouhani’s handling of human rights issues in Iran?

titles: Minimum standards for European airlines
details: WRITTEN QUESTION  by Manolis Mavrommatis (PPE-DE) to the Commission

content: Passengers travelling with the major — mainly European — airlines have repeatedly complained about the restricted space available in economy class.
